dublin_core.dcvalue: Chinn, C. A., Hung, L. C., Zimmerman, R. M., & Duncan, R. G. (2014). How Good Is This Evidence? Students’ Epistemic Competence in Evidence Evaluation. In Joseph L. Polman, Eleni A. Kyza, D. Kevin O'Neill, Iris Tabak, William R. Penuel, A. Susan Jurow, Kevin O'Connor, Tiffany Lee, and Laura D'Amico (Eds.). Learning and Becoming in Practice: The International Conference of the Learning Sciences (ICLS) 2014. Volume 2. Colorado, CO: International Society of the Learning Sciences, pp. 1122-1126.

Inquiry environments in science classes have increasingly incorporated more features of authentic scientific practice. However, relatively few environments have incorporated a critical feature of scientific practice: evaluation of evidence quality. This paper reports results from two studies in middle-school life science classes that investigate seventh graders' competence in evaluating evidence. Overall, we found evidence that students have strong evaluative capabilities that can be built upon in instruction.
Boulder, CO: International Society of the Learning Sciences
How Good Is This Evidence? Students’ Epistemic Competence in Evidence Evaluation
